RMax is committed to communicating not only its safe operating procedures, but all of the information contained in its RMP/PSM Plan to all of its employees. Employees will be made aware of the information through RMP/PSM Plan training. Furthermore, any RMax employee who wishes to further review any or all of the RMP/PSM Plan may arrange to do so during his/her normal working hours with the Plant Manager. RMax's hydrocarbon injection system standard operating procedures will be reviewed at least annually, or more frequently if necessary, to assure they reflect current operating practice, including any changes that may be the result of process chemicals, technology, and/or equipment. A record of this review will be documented in the revision log at the back of the plan.

RMax maintains written safe work practices designed to provide for the control of hazards during certain routine and non-routine work activities. RMax maintains a written Lockout/Tagout Program which has been prepared pursuant to the requirements contained in 29 CFR 1910.147. RMax's program establishes a lockout/tagout system which is designed to prevent the unexpected start up or energization of equipment or release of stored energy that may cause injury to employees. RMax maintains a written procedure to be used when the opening of process equipment/piping included in the hydrocarbon injection system is necessary. This procedure establishes requirements for such activities that will help to minimize the chance of an employee exposure to or accidental release of Blowing Agent during such an activity. RMax maintains a written procedure for the safe collection, storage, and re-introduction into the hydrocarbon injection system of small amounts of Blowing Agent which may be collected during routine maintenance/unloading operations (i.e., filter change, strainer removal). to have an accident before a change is made. RMAX will not compromise safety for convenience, efficiency, or other reasons. Entry to confined spaces will be permitted only after proper training has been conducted. RMAX employees are not permitted to enter a bulk chemical tank. 

It is RMAX's policy to prevent chemical spills by maintaining chemical handling equipment, chemical storage tanks, chemical transfer lines, and containment walls, in excellent condition. In the case of a Major Chemical Spill, employees will immediately evacuate the facility. Employees will not attempt to assist in the clean up of a major chemical spill. In the unlikely event a containment wall fails to restrict a chemical spill, RMAX-certified HAZMAT technicians may be asked to place absorbent barriers in the flow path of the spilled chemical. However, RMAX employees will not be asked to make contact with hazardous spilled chemicals.

Facility & Regulated Substances handled

RMAX manufactures polyisocyanurate foam insulating board. The facility operates under the North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) Code 32615 (urethane and other foam, except polystyrene, manufacturing). The foam board produced at the facility is used in both residential and commercial construction applications. RMAX produces foam board in thickness ranging from 1/2 inch to 4.5 inches.

RMAX uses three main raw materials in the production of foam board: Methylenebis Di-Phenylisocyanate (MDI), Polyol, and Blowing Agents. The Blowing Agent can be either a hydrochlorofluorocarbon or a Hydrocarbon Blowing Agent, typically a blend of Cyclopentane and Isopentane. Several catalysts and fire retardants may also be used depending upon the type of foam board being produced. MDI is considered as part "A" and Polyol combined with blowing agent, catalyst and surfactants are considered as a part "B". Raw materials are all liquids and are stored on-site in bulk tanks. The liquids flow through a series of tanks, static mi

xers and high-pressure pumps towards a pour table. At the pour table, parts "A" and "B" are combined together and injected between the top and bottom facer substrates. RMAX uses several different types of facers, depending upon the type of foam board being produced. Once parts "A" and "B" are combined the liquids exothermically react to form solid foam. 

Isopentane, an integral component of the Hydrocarbon Blowing Agent used by RMAX, is a substance regulated by 40 CFR Part 68. The maximum amount present in RMAX's foam board manufacturing process at any one time is approximately 66,470 pounds. This is above the threshold quantity for Isopentane of 10,000 pounds, as established at 40 CFR 68.130. Therefore, RMAX has determined that the Dallas facility is subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68. RMAX has defined its covered process as that equipment which contains or contacts the Hydrocarbon Blowing Agent, starting at the bulk storage tank loading or fill connection, and extending up to and including, the mix heads located at the Pour Table. This determination was made based on the fact that, once the Blowing Agent is mixed with the other foam components, it is no longer a liquid and is part of a solid, non-flammable product. Thus, the blowing agent is flammable according to the definition 29 CFR 1910.1200(c). 

Through preparation of this Risk Management Plan/Process Safety Management program (RMP/PSM), RMAX has determined that its Dallas Operation is a Program 3 process as defined by 40 CFR 68.10(d). This determination is based on the results of the worst-case release scenario for Isopentane, the location of public receptors being within the distance to the endpoint, and the applicability of 29 CFR 1910.119 to the facility. Thus, RMAX has complied with the requirements for preparation and submittal of a Program 3 RMP as contained in 40 CFR Part 68.

Worst Case Release Scenario

In order to calculate the distance to the endpoint from a worst case release of Blow

ing Agent as Isopentane Blend, the EPA automated program RMPComp v. 1.07 was used to perform the off site consequence analysis. The program provided a conservative estimate for the distance to an endpoint of 1.0 psi overpressure. The quantity of Isopentane used in the worst case release scenario analysis for RMax's Dallas, Texas facility has been determined to be the amount of Blowing Agent contained in the facility's on-site bulk storage tank. In accordance with 40 CFR 68.25(e), and for purposes of calculating the distance to the worst case release endpoint, RMax has assumed that the entire contents of the single largest vessel containing Blowing Agent (66,470 pounds) is released as a vapor which finds an ignition source, and that 10% of the released quantity participates in a resulting explosion. RMax has determined that the distance to an endpoint of 1.0 psi overpressure is 0.3 miles. Using RMax's Latitude and Longitude as a center point, it is estimated that the residential population within 0.3 miles of RMax is 1209 persons. Based on visual reconnaissance, the population density within the affected area will be toward the northeast edge. The remainder of the affected area is occupied by industrial and commercial properties with no residences. Through a review of local street maps and by visual observations of the area surrounding its facility, RMax has identified several types of public receptors within the distance to the endpoint from a worst case release. These types of receptors include: commercial, industrial, and retail facilities. RMax has determined, through examination of the Addison, Texas USGS 1959 (photorevised 1989) 7.5 Minute Topographic Quadrangle Map, that there are no environmental receptors located within the 0.3 mile distance to the endpoint from a worst case release from its facility. Modeling of the worst case release scenario was conducted using the EPA Program ALOHA v. 5.2.3. Meteorological data used for the modeling was taken from availa

ble information of the National Weather Service for the DFW area, and manually input into the program. The plot map footprint was generated from ALOHA using MARPLOT v. 3.2.1. A detailed release footprint overlay was created using the Addison USGS Topographic Quadrangle Map.

Alternate Release Scenarios

RMax has identified two possibilities for the alternative release of Blowing Agent that are more likely to occur than the release described as the worst case release scenario. These possibilities are:

1. Transfer Hose Release of Blowing Agent (During tanker truck unloading); and
2. Process Piping Release of Blowing Agent (Shear of piping within the building by forklift).

A Transfer Hose Release of Blowing Agent occurring during truck unloading is referred to as Alternative Release Scenario #1, while a Process Piping Release of Blowing Agent occurring inside of the manufacturing building is referred to as Alternative Release Scenario #2. RMax has determined, based on the physical properties of the Blowing Agent, that a release from either a transfer hose or from process piping would result in the release/spill of a flammable liquid. The evaporation rate and boiling point of the Blowing Agent are such that a spill would probably result in the formation of a pool of flammable liquid. Thus, in evaluating the consequences of a Transfer Hose Release and a Process Piping Release, RMax has chosen to evaluate the potential radiant heat effects of a pool fire for each type of release.

In order to determine the effects of each Alternative Release Scenario, the following methodology has been used:

(1) Determination of a release quantity and duration of Blowing Agent for each Alternative Release Scenario 
(2) Calculation of the maximum area of the pool of spilled Blowing Agent at a depth of one centimeter for each Alternative Release Scenario. This has been done using the EPA's ALOHA program software. 
(3) Calculation of the distance from the center of the pool to the radiant

heat endpoint of 5 kilowatts per square meter, as specified in 40 CFR 68.22(a)(2)(ii). This radiant heat level could cause second degree burns from a 40-second exposure. This distance has been calculated for a level of concern (LOC) equivalent to the TLV-TWA of cyclopentane using RMPComp and the ALOHA program.

Alternate Release Scenario #1

The quantity of Blowing Agent that may be spilled during a Transfer Hose Release has been estimated based on the following assumptions:

* A complete disconnect of the transfer hose occurs from either from the truck connection or from the fixed piping connection bulkhead; and,
* Blowing Agent continues to be discharged from the truck for 10 minutes.

The release was modeled by the ALOHA program as escape of a liquid to form an evaporating puddle. Based on the tank volume and input parameters at prevailing weather conditions for the area, the ALOHA model predicted an estimated release duration of 58 minutes, and a total amount released of 17,725 lbs. RMPComp estimated a distance of 0.1 miles to the heat radiation endpoint at 5 kilowatts/sq meter. The plot map footprint was generated from ALOHA using MARPLOT v. 3.2.1. A detailed release footprint overlay was created using the Addison USGS Topographic Quadrangle Map. Using RMax's Latitude/Longitude as a center point, the estimated residential population within 0.1 miles of RMax is less than 2 persons. Through a review of local street maps and by visual observations of the area surrounding its facility, RMax has identified several types of public receptors within the 0.1 mile distance to the endpoint from a Transfer Hose Release. These types of receptors include commercial and industrial facilities. RMax has determined through examination of the Addison Topographic Quadrangle Map that there are no environmental receptors located within the 0.1 mile distance from the facility to the endpoint from Alternative Release Scenario #1.

Alternate Release Scenario #2

The quantity of Blowin

g Agent that may be spilled during a Process Piping Release has been estimated based on the following assumptions:

* A complete break of the process piping between the transfer pump and the high pressure injection pumps occurs; and,
* Blowing Agent is discharged from the piping at the maximum pumping rate for 10 minutes.

Note: The most likely location of a process piping release would be within the manufacturing building. However, in order to provide a more conservative estimate of the distance to the specified endpoint of a pool fire, RMax has assumed its building would have no mitigating effects on the consequences of such a fire.

The release was modeled by the ALOHA program as escape of a liquid to form an evaporating puddle. Based on the input parameters and prevailing weather conditions for the area, the ALOHA model predicted an estimated release duration of 21 minutes, and a total amount released of 1,182 lbs. RMPComp estimated a distance of 0.03 miles to the heat radiation endpoint at 5 kilowatts/sq meter. Because of the effects of adjacent buildings and flat topography (so-called "near-field patchiness") using the ALOHA model's urban terrain mode, release dispersion predictions for short distances are considered highly variable. A maximum threat zone of 107 yards was predicted for this scenario. Although ALOHA and MARPLOT did not produce a drawn footprint for this release scenario, an estimated release footprint overlay was created using the Addison USGS Topographic Quadrangle Map. The estimated boundaries of the footprint were presumed to be approximately 50% smaller than the size and extent of the footprint for Alternate Release Scenario #1. 
Using RMax's Latitude/Longitude as a center point, the estimated residential population within 0.03 miles of RMax is 0 persons. Through a review of local street maps and by visual observations of the area surrounding its facility, RMax has identified the types of public receptors within the distance to the endpoint

from a Process Piping Release. These types of receptors include industrial facilities. RMax has determined through examination of the Addison USGS Topographic Quadrangle Map that there are no environmental receptors located within the 0.03 mile distance from the facility to the endpoint from Alternative Release Scenario #2.

General Accident Release Prevention Program & Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Throughout the design of RMax's hydrocarbon injection system and its associated electrical and ventilation systems, various design codes and standards were employed to assure that the process operates in a safe manner. Applicable requirements of the following codes and standards were used throughout the various design stages and were certified by consulting Professional Engineers where required: NFPA 30, NFPA 58, NFPA 70, NFPA 479, SMACNA Round Industrial Duct Construction Standards, ACI 318, AISC, MSS, ASME, AWS, ASTM. Secondary containment for storage areas is provided by virtue of the impervious nature of the buildings. The Hydrocarbon Blowing Agent bulk storage tank has a permanent concrete secondary containment structure. Material storage areas and large containers holding hazardous substances are identified using the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) diamond marking system. 

The Rmax Facility is also protected by a wet pipe sprinkler system.  This system is maintained by the Plant Engineer and is tested on a yearly basis. The Plant Engineer is responsible for overseeing the maintenance of the fire protection system, including testing and inspection of fire extinguishers, testing of the sprinkler system, and testing of enunciators associated with the fire alarm system.

To prevent the potential for ignition sources from either subcontractors or RMax employees), RMax maintains a "Hot Work Permit" Program. A "Hot Work Permit" must be submitted and approved by the Plant Engineer prior to the initiation of any work involving welding, cutting, and/or br

n addition to this training, maintenance personnel are trained in specific safety procedures that are applicable to the maintenance personnel's job tasks, such as RMax's Lockout/Tagout Program, or the written procedure for the opening of process piping/equipment. This additional training will be documented and conducted at a frequency that ensures maintenance personnel are performing their job tasks in a safe manner.

The main activity of RMax maintenance personnel that will ensure the on-going mechanical integrity of its hydrocarbon injection system is the preventive maintenance program. This consists of inspections, testing, and preventive maintenance activities performed on equipment in accordance with the equipment manufacturer's recommendations. RMax maintains a computerized schedule of activities involved in its preventive maintenance program. These activities are printed on a monthly basis and given to those personnel responsible for performing the activity. Maintenance activities, including preventive maintenance inspections and non-routine maintenance performed on RMax's hydrocarbon injection system, will be documented. This documentation shall identify the date of the maintenance activity, the name of the person performing the activity, the serial number or other identifier of the equipment on which the activity is performed, a description of the activity, and the results of the activity. Equipment deficiencies noted by an inspection or test performed on equipment included in the hydrocarbon injection system are communicated to the Plant Engineer and Plant Manager immediately. These deficiencies will be corrected before further use of the system, and in a safe and timely manner when necessary means are taken to assure safe operation of the system.

Upon initial design/construction of its hydrocarbon injection system, RMax will assure that the equipment, as fabricated, is suitable for the process application for which it is to be used, and that process equi

e suitable for the application for which they will be used. Should an identical or manufacturer's recommended part not be available, the replacement will be evaluated by RMax's Management of Change procedures prior to its use in the process. 

In accordance with the requirements contained in 40 CFR 68.69 and 29 CFR 1910.119(f), RMax has developed written operating procedures for its hydrocarbon injection system. These procedures provide clear, concise instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each phase of operation of the system. The primary responsibility for the normal operation of the hydrocarbon injection system will belong to the Chem Mix and Pour Table Operators. In instances other than normal operations, operation of the system will be performed by RMax management personnel or under their direct supervision. Initial startup will be accomplished under direct management supervision. The operating limits, as well as the consequences of deviations of these limits, are explained in the RMP/PSM Plan along with the properties of, and hazards presented by, the use of a Hydrocarbon Blowing Agent. As a part of process modifications to allow the use of a Hydrocarbon Blowing Agent, RMax has made several modifications that will help to prevent employee exposure to, or an accidental release of, the chemical. These include the installation of a hydrocarbon sensor monitoring system (Drager System), the upgrading of its plant ventilation system, and the installation of splash shields at the pour table. 

Inventory control of the Blowing Agent will be administered by RMax's internal procedures for receipt of chemicals. These will help to prevent overfilling of the bulk storage tank, which could result in exposure/accidental release of Blowing Agent. The "quality" of the Blowing Agent received by RMax will be verified through inspection of supplier QA/QC information by RMax employees prior to the unloading of a shipment of the chemical.

The procedure establishes practices that are designed to minimize the chance of the tank being overfilled and/or the accidental release of Blowing Agent during the unloading process. 

Five Year Accident History

RMax Dallas has had no accidental releases from the facility or accidents involving Hydrocarbon Blowing Agent in the previous five years, or throughout its operating history. 

Emergency Response Program

Currently, RMax does not maintain HAZWOPER trained employees on site. For this reason, RMax has chosen to implement an Emergency Action Plan to address its potential facility emergencies. Emergencies that could be expected include: 1) fire / explosion due to the nature of the chemicals / raw materials used / present on-site; and 2) spills or releases of chemicals / raw materials from semi-bulk and/or bulk storage containers. The management-designated RMax personnel who will serve as Emergency Coordinators for the Dallas facility, and who must be notified in case of an emergency, such as a non-sudden release of hazardous substance, fire, explosion, natural disaster, bomb threats or civil disturbances are: Farmers Branch Fire Dept.; Farmers Branch Police Dept.; Plant Manager; Materials Manager; Plant Engineer; Production Manager; Plant Administration; Plant Chemist. The Emergency Coordinator will use professional judgment and experience to determine the action that will be taken, in accordance with the Emergency Action Plan. Decision-making criteria are included that the Emergency Coordinator should use to define situations in which the Emergency Action and Contingency Plan will be implemented. The decision to implement the Emergency Action Plan depends upon whether an imminent or actual situation could threaten human health or the environment. The Emergency Coordinator has the authority to commit the resources needed to carry out the Eme

rgency Action Plan. Since the facility does not require employees to engage in emergency response, the emergency action procedures in the plan meet the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.38(a).

The Emergency Action Plan will be implemented in the following situations:

* Fire and/or Explosion
* Spills or Material Release
* Power Failure
* Natural Disasters, Bomb Threats, and Civil Disturbances
* Medical Response

Emergency procedures are the responsibility of the Emergency Coordinator and not the general employees of RMax or its subcontractors. The Emergency Coordinator or his designee will activate communication systems to notify facility personnel.  If conditions are safe to do so, properly trained employees may extinguish incipient stage fires using portable fire extinguishers.  Such action is not a condition of employment. Upon notification that a fire has started at the facility, the Emergency Coordinator or his designee will notify the fire department. The Emergency Coordinator must identify the character, exact source, amount, and extent of any released materials, and assess possible hazards to human health or the environment. If a spill of material occurs, then the RMAX Spill Control Procedure will be followed. Fire emergencies generally supersede spill emergencies. As necessary, the Emergency Coordinator will notify the appropriate state and local agencies included in the plan's emergency procedural flow diagrams. If the Emergency Coordinator determines there is a threat to human health or to the environment outside the facility, or if greater than the reportable quantity (RQ) of a CERCLA hazardous substance or a SARA Extremely Hazardous Substance (Rmax uses no EHS's) is released, he must report his findings as soon as possible to: local authorities, if evacuation of local areas is advised; State Emergency Response Commission; National Response Center. 

In the case of impending natural disaster (i.e., earthquake, etc.), it is assumed that adequate warning will b

e provided by weather forecasters in the area.  In such situations the Emergency Coordinator will close the facility and send facility personnel home or provide a safe environment at the plant until severe weather has passed.  If a natural disaster strikes unexpectedly, the Emergency Coordinator will instruct personnel to evacuate to an internal rally point. 

In case of serious medical emergency, an ambulance will be summoned by calling 911. RHD Memorial Hospital has been selected as the receiving facility for medical emergency situations. RHD Memorial is approximately 3 miles from the Plant. In case of non-serious, non-emergency situations where medical attention is needed, RMax has First Aid and CPR trained personnel. 

RMAX maintains a list of emergency equipment and capabilities in the EAP. The equipment locations are identified on the site plan in the EAP. Existing equipment is periodically checked and maintained to ensure the quality and efficiency. Emergency phone numbers are posted next to key facility telephones.  A book containing the emergency flowcharts will be maintained at the front desk and at other key facility locations.

RMax's EAP includes Evacuation Procedures. The Evacuation Procedures are also contained in RMax's plant Safety Manual. A map of the building posted at strategic points throughout the facility shows evacuation routes. The Emergency Coordinator or his designee will initiate full evacuation of the affected area(s) as necessary if not already accomplished by sounding the fire alarm.  The supervisor of each department will, if necessary, evacuate all personnel within each department using predetermined routes described in the plan. The Emergency Coordinator will ensure that any injured personnel are evacuated and receive medical attention. During the emergency, the Emergency Coordinator should ensure that in the affected areas of the facility, no waste or other materials that may be incompatible with the released material should be tre

ated, stored, or disposed of until after cleanup procedures are completed. 

Immediately after an emergency, the Emergency Coordinator must ensure that emergency equipment used will be cleaned, decontaminated, and returned to ready status prior to resumption of plant operations in the affected area. Waste materials generated during the emergency must be properly identified, stored and disposed in accordance with State and Federal regulations. Notification must be given to the EPA Regional Administrator, and local authorities if required, that appropriate actions have been completed before resuming operations. A thorough investigation must be conducted into the cause of the emergency incident, and necessary procedural or process modifications made to prevent re-occurrence. 

Decontamination of personnel and equipment must be conducted to reduce or eliminate the transport of contaminants from the emergency area into other areas of the facility, or out into the environment where unprotected personnel may be exposed. The Emergency Coordinator will determine if decontamination should occur and who will conduct the necessary decontamination procedures. Discarded materials, waste materials, or other objects shall be handled in such a way to avoid the potential for spreading contamination, creating a sanitary hazard, or causing litter to be left on-site.  In general, material that has visible signs of contamination (i.e., waste oil, oil-contaminated soil) will be classified by the Emergency Coordinator as potentially contaminated material. 

New employees will be familiarized with emergency response procedures as part of hazard communication. An annual review is made to update the Emergency Action Plan. Under the following conditions, the Emergency Action and Contingency Plan will be reviewed and revised:

* Upon consummation of arrangements with local fire department, police department, hospital, and commercial clean-up contractors
* Plan fails during emergency, where unan

ticipated problems arise or emergency contacts not properly equipped to handle a situation
* Personnel changes if Emergency Coordinator change
* Facility is altered due to physical modifications or new emergency equipment 
* Change in process operations or chemicals, or new processes or modifications

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

RMAX believes that the elements of its RMP/PSM program, as described and implemented, will ensure ongoing continued safety improvement. As improved technology, control systems, monitoring systems, or mitigation approaches become available, RMAX will evaluate these for technical and economic feasibility. Organization changes or additional training which are deemed appropriate to enhance or improve safety will also be given consideration as needed, and incorporated into the procedures for Management of Change.
